message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and hypercholesterolemia, and echocardiography results suggest that her ventricular function is worsening. Among the options, enalapril is an ACE inhibitor commonly used to treat heart failure by improving ventricular function. Digoxin is used to treat arrhythmias and diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker often used to treat hypertension. Atorvastatin is a lipid-lowering medication used to treat hypercholesterolemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease, which can cause myocardial infarction and subsequent left ventricular dilation and decreased ejection fraction. Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor that can prevent worsening of ventricular function by reducing left ventricular dilation and improving ejection fraction. Digoxin is used to treat heart failure but does not prevent worsening of ventricular function. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used for hypertension and angina but does not prevent worsening of ventricular function. Atorvastatin is a statin used for hypercholesterolemia but does not prevent worsening of ventricular function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has coronary artery disease, hypercholesterolemia, and arterial hypertension, which puts her at risk for further myocardial infarctions and worsening ventricular function. Enalapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, which can reduce afterload and help prevent further damage to the heart. Digoxin is used to treat heart failure symptoms but does not prevent further damage. Diltiazem and atorvastatin may have some benefit but are not the most likely preventive measure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has arterial hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia, all of which are risk factors for heart failure. Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, is used to prevent heart failure in patients with high blood pressure and heart damage. Digoxin and diltiazem are used to treat heart failure, but not prevent it, and atorvastatin is used to lower cholesterol levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and hypercholesterolemia, both of which increase her risk for worsening ventricular function. Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor that has been shown to improve ventricular function, prevent left ventricular dilation, and reduce the incidence of heart failure in patients with coronary heart disease. Digoxin and Diltiazem are not indicated for the prevention of worsening ventricular function, and Atorvastatin is useful for lowering LDL cholesterol but does not directly impact ventricular function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and hypercholesterolemia, and her worsening ventricular function suggests she may have developed heart failure. Enalapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that can help prevent worsening ventricular function by reducing preload and afterload. Digoxin is used for symptom control but does not prevent worsening ventricular function. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that can help reduce heart rate and blood pressure but does not prevent worsening ventricular function. Atorvastatin is a statin used to lower cholesterol levels but does not prevent worsening ventricular function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s condition has worsened, indicating that the medication she was taking is not sufficient. Among the options, only Enalapril helps prevent left ventricular dilatation and improve ejection fraction in patients with heart failure. Digoxin is used to control heart rate, Diltiazem is used for hypertension, and Atorvastatin is used to lower cholesterol.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history suggests that she has not been compliant with her medication, which is a contributing factor to her worsening ventricular function. Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor commonly used to treat hypertension and coronary artery disease, and has been shown to improve ventricular function in patients with heart failure. Digoxin is mainly used to control heart rate and improve symptoms in patients with atrial fibrillation. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker primarily used to treat hypertension and angina. Atorvastatin is a statin used to treat hypercholesterolemia, but does not directly affect ventricular function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has known coronary artery disease and hypercholesterolemia, but the issue at hand is left ventricular dilation and reduced ejection fraction. Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor that can slow the progression of left ventricular dysfunction and improve clinical outcomes. Digoxin is used to control heart rate, diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension, and atorvastatin is a medication used to lower cholesterol levels, but none of these are specifically targeted towards preventing ventricular dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction, both of which can lead to heart failure. The fact that she rarely takes her medication suggests that she is not receiving appropriate treatment to prevent heart failure. Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor that can help prevent worsening ventricular function in patients with heart failure. Digoxin is used to treat heart failure, but not prevent it. Diltiazem and atorvastatin are not indicated for heart failure management.
